commit_message:
Make tests pass in 2022

Background:
As part of my work on reproducible builds for openSUSE, I check that software still gives identical build results in the future.
The usual offset is +15 years, because that is how long I expect some software will be used in some places.
This showed up failing tests in our package build.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

This makes it expire 1 year in the future to model realistic tokens.

NOTE: in addition to the orginal backport, this patch adds the following
changes. The changes has to be combined into a single patch in order to
avoid circular dependencies.

1. fixed the hadcoded token expiration date in
keystonemiddleware/tests/unit/client_fixtures.py. This is using the same
technique in the original backport.

2. fixed bandit complains in keystonemiddleware/auth_token/_request.py.
The request environment variable names are not tokens. We'll need to
mark them as false positives so bandit can stop chirping.

Change-Id: I73bde68be53afff4e8dff12d756b8381f34b2adb
(cherry picked from commit 4a4c96ce9b28ed54f93a21ca405c5b34ef3c3429)

subject: Cleanup doc/requirements.txt
messages:
[{'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2020-01-14 09:18:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-01-14 17:04:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2020-01-14 21:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there any particular reason to do this? global-requirements.txt still uses the python_version suffix'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2020-01-17 09:48:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Is there any particular reason to do this? global-requirements.txt
 > still uses the python_version suffix

Keystone dropped python 2 support, so it isn't required to explicitly mention about the python version for the sphinx requirement."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2020-01-17 19:31:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > Is there any particular reason to do this? global-requirements.txt
 > > still uses the python_version suffix
 > 
 > Keystone dropped python 2 support, so it isn't required to
 > explicitly mention about the python version for the sphinx
 > requirement.

I think it would still be best for it to match global-requirements."}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2020-01-20 11:28:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > > Is there any particular reason to do this? global-requirements.txt
 > > > still uses the python_version suffix
 > >
 > > Keystone dropped python 2 support, so it isn't required to
 > > explicitly mention about the python version for the sphinx
 > > requirement.
 > 
 > I think it would still be best for it to match global-requirements.

Yes that makes sense. I saw some other projects following the same so I updated [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701621/2/doc/requirements.txt
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692045/8/doc/requirements.txt"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix hieradata for Heat API timeout

puppet-tripleo uses heat::wsgi::apache_api and not heat::wsgi::apache so
we need to update the hieradata. Also let's move it to the heat-api
service and not in base.

Depends-On: I7da55899b9108daced7adb8f82bdb58fcf97aa09
Change-Id: I2ae2f498c70d2c6d90c6f760d7d4a09a36403722
(cherry picked from commit d2db2292e59fe56fc969c93a60a985178bf89f09)

commit_message:
Make sure requested mtu is set

The 'options' keyword for setting mtu in 'set interface' does not
set mtu and it seems to ignore/fail the request silently.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-15 21:39:47.000000000', 'message': "WIP objects: automatically detect whether engine facade is used

While we added new_facade object attribute to framework and it has its
niche and used in some stadium subprojects, it's not ideal because it's
global to an object. Meaning that if you mark an object for new_facade =
True, *all* business logic using the object must also switch to new
facade in the same step, which is a pain and sometimes close to
impossible to do without changing thousands loosely related lines of
code in multiple modules. It would be nice to instead use objects as
usual in different contexts - some using engine facade and some still
using session.begin(...) - and allow the OVO framework to pick the right
way to nest subtransactions.

This patch does exactly that. We call an internal function from oslo.db
and check whether it raises an exception. If it does, it means that the
engine facade is not used; otherwise, we use the new style of nested
transactions management.

By default, if session is not active when OVO action is called, we stick
to the old facade. Once we are done with switching the rest of the
plugin code / OVO objects to the new facade, we will rip off the
transitionary logic.

Change-Id: Ia05df925eccf3c9d397748f282e995203a058de9
Partially-Implements: blueprint enginefacade-switch
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

code in multiple modules. It would be nice to instead use objects as
usual in different contexts - some using engine facade and some still
using session.begin(...) - and allow the OVO framework to pick the right
way to nest subtransactions.

This patch does exactly that. We call an internal function from oslo.db
and check whether it raises an exception. If it does, it means that the
engine facade is not used; otherwise, we use the new style of nested
transactions management.

By default, if session is not active when OVO action is called, we stick
to the old facade. Once we are done with switching the rest of the
plugin code / OVO objects to the new facade, we will rip off the
transitionary logic.

Change-Id: Ia05df925eccf3c9d397748f282e995203a058de9
Partially-Implements: blueprint enginefacade-switch
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
objects: automatically detect whether engine facade is used

While we added new_facade object attribute to framework and it has its
niche and used in some stadium subprojects, it's not ideal because it's
global to an object. Meaning that if you mark an object for new_facade =
True, *all* business logic using the object must also switch to new
facade in the same step, which is a pain and sometimes close to
impossible to do without changing thousands loosely related lines of
code in multiple modules. It would be nice to instead use objects as
usual in different contexts - some using engine facade and some still
using session.begin(...) - and allow the OVO framework to pick the right
way to nest subtransactions.

This patch does exactly that. We call an internal function from oslo.db
and check whether it raises an exception. If it does, it means that the
engine facade is not used; otherwise, we use the new style of nested
transactions management.

By default, if session is not active when OVO action is called, we stick
to the old facade. Once we are done with switching the rest of the
plugin code / OVO objects to the new facade, we will rip off the
transitionary logic.

Change-Id: Ia05df925eccf3c9d397748f282e995203a058de9
Partially-Implements: blueprint enginefacade-switch
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-14 08:16:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add retries to update trunk port

In [1] retry of trunk update was added to avoid StaleDataError
exceptions to fail to set trunk port or subports to ACTIVE state.
But it was only partial fix for the issue descibed in related bug
and from [2] we know that it still can happen on high load systems
from time to time.
So I was checking this issue and reported bug again and I found out
that retry was added only in _process_trunk_subport_bindings()
method. But StaleDataError can be raised also in other cases where
the same trunk is updated, e.g. in update_trunk_status() method.

So this commit adds same retry mechanism to all trunk.update() actions
in services.trunk.rpc.server module.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662236/
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1733197

Conflicts:
    neutron/services/trunk/rpc/server.py

Change-Id: I10e3619d5f3600ea97ed695321bb691dece3181f
Partial-Bug: #1828375
(cherry picked from commit ade35a233edb5c9489cc3a68ae00672fb328f63d)
'}]
commit_message:
Add retries to update trunk port

In [1] retry of trunk update was added to avoid StaleDataError
exceptions to fail to set trunk port or subports to ACTIVE state.
But it was only partial fix for the issue descibed in related bug
and from [2] we know that it still can happen on high load systems
from time to time.
So I was checking this issue and reported bug again and I found out
that retry was added only in _process_trunk_subport_bindings()
method. But StaleDataError can be raised also in other cases where
the same trunk is updated, e.g. in update_trunk_status() method.

So this commit adds same retry mechanism to all trunk.update() actions
in services.trunk.rpc.server module.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662236/
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1733197

Conflicts:
    neutron/services/trunk/rpc/server.py

Change-Id: I10e3619d5f3600ea97ed695321bb691dece3181f
Partial-Bug: #1828375
(cherry picked from commit ade35a233edb5c9489cc3a68ae00672fb328f63d)

commit_message:
tools: Allow custom base images for kubeadm AIO

This change adds support for modifying the kubeadm AIO base image using
Ansible playbook vars. Using a custom base image allows users behind a
corporate proxy server to download custom-hosted images behind their
firewall, enabling quicker setup times.

Change-Id: I399d120a2d884da1d8530cf0fb20721c5b7259e6
Signed-off-by: Drew Walters <andrew.walters@att.com>

commit_message:
Make sure audit middleware use own context

Keystone audit middleware requires to iterate req.context as dict,
but Glance requires to access req.context.read_only.
When glance enabled audit, they are conflict with each other.
This patch fix this issue by store audit context in
req.environ['audit.context']

Change-Id: Ib9a62a4cd0b7b9ffb9fa2d6440e8072d45ee0fee
Closes-Bug: #1809101
Signed-off-by: Leehom Li <feli5@cisco.com>
(cherry picked from commit 82707e15a5bce8de2d33b1c865c96844c9770580)

commit_message:
A fond farewell to Morgan Fainberg

Morgan Fainberg has acknowledged that he no longer has sufficient
opportunity to serve as a vulnerability manager for OpenStack.
Thanks so much, Morgan, for all your assistance over the years.
Hopefully we'll still see you around from time to time!

Change-Id: Ie93e5717981a938c465e42d8c207bd92bbd870c1

commit_message:
Fix role-addition.yaml automation playbook

The call to ansible-galaxy was wrong:
- wrong init path (tripleo_validations/roles instead of roles)
- missing role name

This patch adds a sort method to keep the job lists (check & gate)
sorted when adding a new role.

Change-Id: I9cfe5a83cd804f4793d6f4a73821a21ce64f40f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-23 08:45:48.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Delete NAT entry first on any FIP update

For now while updating FIP  check if port or logical_ip
has changed and only then we deleted the NAT entry.

Unfortunately each time when FIP update occurs the
method _create_or_update_floatingip() is used. It first deletes
LSP pointed by FIP and adds it again along with new NAT entries.
Based on author comment this actions are required.

So if we don't update FIP with logical_ip or new port_id,
like update a description, the NAT entries gets duplicated.

Since all is wrapped withing a transaction and to not wait for
proper fix (this code need sa refactor based on commments with NAT
external_id column) I think thats safe just to delete the NAT entry
in such situation like described above.

(cherry picked from commit 45ae9dfb7d5acacc72fcf9f071a9db1beb0ca972)

Change-Id: Iea532e2a02b7992305d1b90aa040e064901c340c
Related-Bug: #1859977
"}, {'created': '2020-01-23 11:50:17.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Delete NAT entry first on any FIP update

commit_message:
[OVN] Delete NAT entry first on any FIP update

For now while updating FIP  check if port or logical_ip
has changed and only then we deleted the NAT entry.

Unfortunately each time when FIP update occurs the
method _create_or_update_floatingip() is used. It first deletes
LSP pointed by FIP and adds it again along with new NAT entries.
Based on author comment this actions are required.

So if we don't update FIP with logical_ip or new port_id,
like update a description, the NAT entries gets duplicated.

Since all is wrapped withing a transaction and to not wait for
proper fix (this code need sa refactor based on commments with NAT
external_id column) I think thats safe just to delete the NAT entry
in such situation like described above.

(cherry picked from commit 45ae9dfb7d5acacc72fcf9f071a9db1beb0ca972)

Change-Id: Iea532e2a02b7992305d1b90aa040e064901c340c
Related-Bug: #1859977

commit_message:
ETSI-NFV SOL 001 translation: BlockStorage

Currently heat-translator supports translation of TOSCA Simple Profile
for YAML[1] and TOSCA Simple Profile for NFV[2] only.
This commit enables to translation of the follwoing type defined in
ETSI NFV-SOL 001[3].
- tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.VirtualBlockStorage

Thanks, Tin. But I see at least two difficulties here: 1. in ceph-rgw we are using configmap instead of secrets, and 2. I'm not sure how to populate secret with data from another secret (ceph.client.admin.keyring)."}, {'account_id': 18511, 'date': '2020-01-28 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2020-01-28 16:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> Thanks, Tin. But I see at least two difficulties here: 1. in
 > ceph-rgw we are using configmap instead of secrets, and 2. I'm not

 > (ceph.client.admin.keyring).

 > Thanks, Tin. But I see at least two difficulties here: 1. in
 > ceph-rgw we are using configmap instead of secrets, and 2. I'm not
 > sure how to populate secret with data from another secret
 > (ceph.client.admin.keyring).

That I will have to look, but giving this a second glance, I notice this chart already has a bootstrap job framework in place [0] - wouldn't it just be confusing now there is another bootstrap job.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/src/branch/master/ceph-rgw/values.yaml#L417-L428"}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Tin, only this part was implemented. I mean, there was no bootstrap job which is using this part of code.'}, {'account_id': 29974, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:50:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30777, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:57:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

> Can we not reuse this [0]?
 > 
 > [0] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/src/branch/master/helm-toolkit/templates/manifests/_job-bootstrap.tpl

I don't think the helm toolkit template is completely compatible with the job proposed in this change. For instance this job requires multiple init containers.

Also, as Dmitrii has pointed out, there are other ceph charts which don't use the helm toolkit template for their bootstrap jobs currently. Because of this, I don't think this change should be blocked for not using the toolkit here.

However that is not to say that in the future the toolkit template shouldn't be extended, and the ceph charts updated to use it."}, {'account_id': 22636, 'date': '2020-01-28 18:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2020-01-28 18:53:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-22 15:19:03.000000000', 'message': 'Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

At some point, the file names that are checked for existence when
determining to apply the logic for --skip-deploy-identifier must have
changed.

Since the file check was not updated, it was checking for a file that
would never exist, and so the ansible tasks were always run (or re-run).

Effectively, --skip-deploy-identifier was broken and it had no effect.

This patch updates the file check to use the correct name, and also
checks the right file per step.

Change-Id: Ia01a10c488d22e38cd86b0117e9c048ea5cc3298
Closes-Bug: #1860566
'}, {'created': '2020-01-22 15:22:38.000000000', 'message': '[TRAIN ONLY] Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

At some point, the file names that are checked for existence when
determining to apply the logic for --skip-deploy-identifier must have
changed.

Since the file check was not updated, it was checking for a file that
would never exist, and so the ansible tasks were always run (or re-run).

Effectively, --skip-deploy-identifier was broken and it had no effect.

This patch updates the file check to use the correct name, and also
checks the right file per step. It only applies to Train since on
master, these files were switched to write out per container files in a
directory, and the fix was addressed at that time.

Change-Id: Ia01a10c488d22e38cd86b0117e9c048ea5cc3298
Closes-Bug: #1860566
'}]
commit_message:
[TRAIN ONLY] Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

At some point, the file names that are checked for existence when
determining to apply the logic for --skip-deploy-identifier must have
changed.

Since the file check was not updated, it was checking for a file that
would never exist, and so the ansible tasks were always run (or re-run).

Effectively, --skip-deploy-identifier was broken and it had no effect.

This patch updates the file check to use the correct name, and also
checks the right file per step. It only applies to Train since on
master, these files were switched to write out per container files in a
directory, and the fix was addressed at that time.

Change-Id: Ia01a10c488d22e38cd86b0117e9c048ea5cc3298
Closes-Bug: #1860566

commit_message:
Add network vip mapping into service data

Make it possible to resolve network virtual ips from
within a service template. The data is transported in
the existing ServiceData property wich is wired into
all services.

The data can be consumed in service templates, replacing
the need for hiera interpolation for network virtual ips.

Related: RHBZ#1791338
Closes-Bug: #1860545
Change-Id: I24c239174d8d066bd2cb4300a21fa1d38a3e80cd
(cherry picked from commit eac636c9e66cde459bc1e1802a67f00136b9734e)

commit_message:
Add network vip mapping into service data

Make it possible to resolve network virtual ips from
within a service template. The data is transported in
the existing ServiceData property wich is wired into
all services.

The data can be consumed in service templates, replacing
the need for hiera interpolation for network virtual ips.

Related: RHBZ#1791338
Closes-Bug: #1860545
Change-Id: I24c239174d8d066bd2cb4300a21fa1d38a3e80cd
(cherry picked from commit eac636c9e66cde459bc1e1802a67f00136b9734e)

With our continues development of DVR  Openflow solution and the evolution of OVN, we have done some analysis. The feature set in OVN is richer than the current DVR solution & is gaining momentum in the community. So we are intending to transition our DVR efforts to OVN and stop further development in DVR. We believe this will better help community and networking project. Intel will be glad to help customers transition from DVR to OVN. Let us know if you have any feedback to us.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-23 01:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

the project is cancelled as we are moving to OVN, which also uses openflow to implement L3'}]

commit_message:
Introduce a new L3 agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the L3 agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood).

This change also includes the creation of a layer of
abstraction for the L3 agent, thus decoupling it from the backend:
- Linux kernel utilities, iptables, namespaces (like before)
- Open vSwitch (the backend being introduced)
- <open possibilities>

Related-Bug: #1705536

Co-Authored-By: Igor D.C. <igor.duarte.cardoso@intel.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe

Switch source installs to build from git

Previously this was using the release defined in global requirements but
this prevents us pulling in critical fixes to unblock testing by
updating the sha of tempest.
e Please enter the commit message for your changes. Lines starting

job.

Adapt tempestconf job to use integrated repo

Adapt the tempestconf job to use a variant of the integrated repo's
AIO test job.

Also mark tripleo CI job as non voting as it is failing.

commit_message:
Fix the interface filenames for Red Hat amphora images

Code was not using the correct filenames for the 'route',
'route6', 'rule' and 'rule6' files on Red Hat images.
Changed to use config option 'agent_server_network_file'
if it's specified, else the file of the correct name, and
added unit tests for each.

Change-Id: I335287da66524d026f0c42086d885b478c568bbd
Task: 37881
Story: 2007051

subject: Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

Added the skydive-agent to the subnode in the zuul job definition. Still have to see if skydive is installed correctly at the gate with the 'stack' user change from PS7."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-12 20:59:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-12 21:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Workflow-1

Patchset 9: Still need to see if the gate will be able to successfully install the Skydive devstack plugin after the stack user change in PS7. PS9 also changes the assertion: Instead of checking which nodes we see the ping to the FIP, we now look for the ping to the fixed IP instead. This is because upstream the ping goes out *from* the main controller node, so of course we'd see a ping to the FIP on that node. By checking where we see a ping to the fixed IP, we guarantee that we should only see that ping on the node that executed the NAT from the FIP to the fixed IP, which if DVR is working properly, should only be on the compute node."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-13 14:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-13 14:22:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

"neutron-tempest-plugin-dvr-multinode-scenario-rocky" ran the test and it passed. The other 2 multinode job failed, seems unrelated to this patch. I do want to recheck a few times to make sure the test is stable.

I also want to see that the job run times didn't go up too much.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-12-13 14:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

neutron-tempest-plugin-dvr-multinode-scenario-queens seems to fail because it is running on bionic, but it should be pinned to xenial, I'll do a separate patch to fix that."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-13 15:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Neat, thanks for looking :)'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-12-13 17:09:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

+1000 :) I need to read carefully, but looks awesome :D'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-13 18:03:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Latest run shows that the test passed successfully on the job against Rocky, but the test skipped in another job against master. It skipped here:
http://logs.openstack.org/94/624494/9/check/neutron-tempest-plugin-dvr-multinode-scenario/5bec6b4/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-12-13_15_30_36_882297

It skipped because the test needsa multi node setup (specifically at least 1 api/network node, and 1 compute node). It tests this by creating a router, creating a VM, and skipping if they both landed on the same host. Upstream CI multi node jobs spawn 2 machines: All-in-one, and a dedicated compute node. Reason why the test passed in one case but skipped in another is that the VM may be scheduled to either the all-in-one node (which is where the router would end up being scheduled to...) or the dedicated compute node.

The fix would be to create the router, record it's scheduled host, and then use the Nova admin API to force spawn a VM on a different node. If a different node doesn't exist, skip the test."}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-12-13 20:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

This patch is pure gold :)
We need to make it somehow compatible with networking-ovn but we don뗪 implement  the dvr extension [0]. Also we need to check if networking-ovn sets the distributed flag when north/south is also distributed (east/west is distributed by default) and 

[0] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1565126'}, {'account_id': 26882, 'date': '2018-12-13 21:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26882, 'date': '2018-12-13 21:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Nice patch :))'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2018-12-14 05:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(3 comments)

Nice patch :)'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2018-12-14 15:19:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 19:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 19:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 19:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 19:45:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Workflow-1

Patchset 10 addresses comments from patchset 8.

Patchset 9 addresses the issue I outlined on Dec 13 1:03 PM as a comment on the patch itself. TL;DR: The test cannot assume the cloud topology and has to force the VM to be created on a different hypervisor than the router. That forced me to use admin credentials when creating the VM. Nova doesn't allow using admin credentials to create a VM in a specific project (unlike Neutron), so I had to create some other test resources in the admin project too."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-12-18 20:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 20:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 20:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-18 20:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Workflow-1

PS12 addresses comments by Brian on PS11.

I still want to run this on upstream CI a few times before I remove the WIP flag.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-12-18 23:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-19 13:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-19 15:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Workflow-1

The test passed against master, and ran in to the same issue in both the queens and rocky:

queens:
http://logs.openstack.org/94/624494/13/check/neutron-tempest-plugin-dvr-multinode-scenario-queens/d12229c/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-12-19_13_42_27_320424

rocky:
http://logs.openstack.org/94/624494/13/check/neutron-tempest-plugin-dvr-multinode-scenario-rocky/f39769f/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-12-19_13_52_26_043666

When building skydive from source:
"Makefile:8: recipe for target 'browser.js' failed"

My take on it is that this is probably a good example of why we should be grabbing a released Skydive version, and not building it from source. We're not gating on Skydive changes here, we're just using Skydive as a tool, so I think the next step is to enhance the Skydive devstack plugin to have the ability to install a released version, before we merge this patch.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-19 16:02:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I've just spoken with Sylvain Afchain, a Skydive developer, who said he'll send a Devstack plugin patch tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-12-19 16:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-19 16:51:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-20 16:48:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Sylvain merged the devstack change I needed, I'll check it out."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-20 16:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

https://github.com/skydive-project/skydive/pull/1545/commits/02b3af21bcbce7f361e98454dbd3c528d67329da'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-20 18:49:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-20 21:54:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Workflow-1

Hmm.

1) There's a bunch of unrelated failures
2) Skydive installation from binary worked
3) The test skipped when ran against queens, I need to check this out
4) The test failed against master, Skydive didn't see the expected traffic on any node.

So, more work to do here."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-20 22:25:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

OK, one problem I'm identified is that SKYDIVE_INSTALL_MODE is not set on the compute node on any branch. It does successfully build from source on the master run, but it fails to build on the queens run. On that run, stack.sh failed on the compute node (due to failing to build Skydive, due to SKYDIVE_INSTALL_MODE not set to binary), yet the job continues and runs the tests.

1) If stack.sh fails on a node we should fail the job and stop
2) I need to understand why SKYDIVE_INSTALL_MODE is not being set on the compute node.

The test does run on master, but fails due to some other reason as I noted in the previous comment. I haven't looked in to this yet."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:07:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:10:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Workflow-1

Two changes in the latest patchset:
1) .zuul.yaml changes configures the Skydive devstack plugin on the subnode to install Skydive from binary instead of source (it was only doing that on the main node in the previous patchset)
2) We now wait until the capture is in place before continuing with the test. Skydive's Python capture_create is asynchronous, it returns before the capture is present on all devices, so the helper now grabs the capture's count value (how many devices the capture is present on), and compares it against the number of devices in the query used to create the capture.

I've been collaborating with Sylvain Afchain, and he added the 'count' attribute on the Python library Capture object, and just cut a new release to pip, 0.5.0, so the next step is to bump to it in g/r."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:11:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:11:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Workflow-1

Bump to skydive-client 0.5.0 in this repo. Now to send a patch to g/r.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2018-12-21 18:38:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Workflow-1

Sent https://review.openstack.org/626963 to bump skydive-client in global requirements.

Latest patchset adds:
1) Simplifies capture query to not use 'HasEither' directive - that requires a Skydive version not yet released.
2) Moves the Skydive helpers from a mixin (eww) to the scenarios test base class."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-03 21:17:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-04 16:02:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Two issues remain:

1) The line to add the capture cleanup sometimes fails, when accessing capture.uuid. Seems like sometimes capture is a dict, and sometimes it's an object. Not sure why this is yet.
2) Seems like when running at the gate, the capture doesn't seem to work."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-15 21:23:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

As far as problem 1, capture.uuid getting a dict keyerror, it's because the Skydive python library create_capture method changed it's return type. It differs between 0.4.5 (what is used at the gate), and 0.5.0 (the latest). So I have to figure out why the gate is not using the latest version, and that should fix that problem."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-16 18:21:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

The gate is using skydive-client 0.5.0 on the master branch and 0.4.5 on queens and rocky which explains the different failure there.

As far as the 2nd issue, I'm making progress there as well - Skydive isn't seeing the traffic where it should because the ping to the FIP is failing :) So I'll figure out why, and also change it to assert that the ping succeeded before continuing with the test."}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:47:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-16 21:48:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Workflow-1

This patch should work now on all 3 branches. Let's see :)"}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-17 21:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 8873, 'date': '2019-01-17 21:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19: Workflow-1

This new patchset should finally resolve issues on the stable branches, as those use an older version of the Python skydive-client API wrapper.

One issue remains, I think unrelated to Skydive, is that the test fails to ping the VM's FIP at the gate but works fine locally. I haven't had to chance to troubleshoot why this happens."}]

[{'created': '2018-12-11 21:17:03.000000000', 'message': 'Add a Skydive based test

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
'}, {'created': '2018-12-11 21:19:10.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Add a Skydive based test

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
'}, {'created': '2018-12-12 14:59:49.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

Skydive [1] is an open source network topology and protocols
analyzer that gives you a comprehensive way to understand
what is happening in your infrastructure.

Miguel Angel Ajo Pelayo and Daniel Alvarez Sanchez gave
a lightning talk [2] in the Denver PTG, showing how
it'd be possible to use Skydive's injection and capture
functionality to test new scenarios that Tempest is unable
to cover.

This patch serves two purposes:
1) Set up the infrastructure to allow Skydive to be used
   in tests.
2) Write the first test that uses Skydive as a reference.

The test asserts that if Neutron claims that a router
is distributed, then traffic to a VM's FIP is indeed
distributed (i.e. goes directly to the compute node
hosting the VM, and not via a gateway or network node).

[1] http://skydive.network/
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-dataplane-testing

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
"}, {'created': '2018-12-12 16:39:25.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

a lightning talk [2] in the Denver PTG, showing how
it'd be possible to use Skydive's injection and capture
functionality to test new scenarios that Tempest is unable
to cover.

This patch serves two purposes:
1) Set up the infrastructure to allow Skydive to be used
   in tests.
2) Write the first test that uses Skydive as a reference.

The test asserts that if Neutron claims that a router
is distributed, then traffic to a VM's FIP is indeed
distributed (i.e. goes directly to the compute node
hosting the VM, and not via a gateway or network node).

[1] http://skydive.network/
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-dataplane-testing

commit_message:
Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

Skydive [1] is an open source network topology and protocols
analyzer that gives you a comprehensive way to understand
what is happening in your infrastructure.

Miguel Angel Ajo Pelayo and Daniel Alvarez Sanchez gave
a lightning talk [2] in the Denver PTG, showing how
it'd be possible to use Skydive's injection and capture
functionality to test new scenarios that Tempest is unable
to cover.

This patch serves two purposes:
1) Set up the infrastructure to allow Skydive to be used
   in tests.
2) Write the first test that uses Skydive as a reference.

The test asserts that if Neutron claims that a router
is distributed, then traffic to a VM's FIP is indeed
distributed (i.e. goes directly to the compute node
hosting the VM, and not via a gateway or network node).

The patch also reuses the list_AZs and list_hypervisors
methods from another test, and moves them to a common base
class.

[1] http://skydive.network/
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-dataplane-testing

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88

[{'created': '2020-01-15 10:08:51.000000000', 'message': 'Validate the playboooks metadata structure

This patch add a custom ansible-lint rule to enforce the structure of
the validations playbooks:

*ValidationHasMetadataRule*:
Throw an ansible-lint error if:
- the *hosts* key is empty or not found,
- *vars* dictionary is missing,
- *metadata* dict is missing in *vars*
- *name*/*description*/*groups* keys are missing or found with a wrong
  data type
- the validation belongs to one or several groups NOT in the official list of
  groups (groups.yaml)

*YAMLLINT*:
- Enable yamllint check in tox linters
- WIP Fix detected yamllint errors

Change-Id: If233286aa9f4299f02f13dc34f1e8c05d89df851
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e50e1a067de6d359d8e95c909859c30cf5d6912e)

commit_message:
Validate the playboooks metadata structure

This patch add a custom ansible-lint rule to enforce the structure of
the validations playbooks:

*ValidationHasMetadataRule*:
Throw an ansible-lint error if:
- the *hosts* key is empty or not found,
- *vars* dictionary is missing,
- *metadata* dict is missing in *vars*
- *name*/*description*/*groups* keys are missing or found with a wrong
  data type
- the validation belongs to one or several groups NOT in the official list of
  groups (groups.yaml)

*YAMLLINT*:
- Enable yamllint check in tox linters
- WIP Fix detected yamllint errors

Change-Id: If233286aa9f4299f02f13dc34f1e8c05d89df851
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e50e1a067de6d359d8e95c909859c30cf5d6912e)
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Run multinode and undercloud jobs nova-less

None of these jobs actually use nova, so it should be possible to run
them without.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/703038/

Change-Id: I472f8d146d865316da4066cc6845e23c8808c907
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

[{'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-02-27 09:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-27 11:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/639605/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 55m 50s'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2019-02-28 01:19:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi, Igor. This commit is changing a lot of stuff and it makes me confusing what these changes is for. Is there any big picture you mind?

My curious part is relation of 'backend' / 'router_info' / 'l3-agent' and hierarchy of them."}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-02-28 02:42:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Yang, let me share the document I wrote about this 2 days ago: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1tBeOp8uCKcpTkby4tUPZTNUxl9GqrB96. This patch is proposal 2.

But long story short, my goal here is to make agent.py be backend-agnostic, that's all.

If this patch goes forward, then https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528336/ will be abandoned.

The way I'm making agent.py backend-agnostic is to keep using RouterInfos for all instantiated routers (dvr, ha, etc) and to introduce this new Backend entity for backend-specific agent data/state (that don't relate to any particular RouterInfo).

A lot of the changes you see here are actually noise from renaming RouterInfo to LinuxRouterInfo (with new RouterInfo being top parent class/interface). For that reason alone I feel very tempted to just use your terminology instead (RouterInfo and BaseRouterInfo, respectively), but then it's not as clear when reading the code whether we're in the presence of Linux-based RouterInfos or OVS-based RouterInfos, etc."}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-02-28 02:50:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am using some qualifiers to help me think about this re-arch:

- agent-wide or backend-agnostic -> that would be agent.py, its mixins, etc.

- backend-specific or backend-wide -> each of the children of Backend, for agent-related stuff particular to an implementation

- router-specific -> each of the leaf children of RouterInfo.. ideally, they would be completely unaware of implementation backend but we are very far from that (so the code say, for DvrLocalRouter, is Linux-specific).

When I say agent_mode and agent_backend in the pdf, I mean this: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-February/002403.html'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-02-28 03:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-28 04:46:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/639605/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 38m 01s'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-01 22:53:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Here is my vision for a future, better architecture (a second refactor) of the L3 agent: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1z5RcQl64YGPcEJVy2B3XnwM6hgn-4vUs
However, right now, the most important is to get the agent.py backend-agnostic (as was originally presented by the community as a requirement to accept the dvr-bridge work), but to do that without dual-purposing RouterInfo and without having workarounds like classmethods and classvars from 528336 that have created quite a few challenges as we work on dvr-bridge.'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2019-03-04 02:18:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

First, I admire yours courages act since l3 related code is really confusing to be refactored. I felt you are drawing a big picture, not a simple modification, so my  comments are related to general problems that I felt. It's unrelated to your fix but I hope it makes a little bit helpful for your hard work.

- Neutron L3 code is heavily using mixins but there is no common interface. I think feature of 'dvr', 'edge' can be extracted to common interface which could be attached to router_info. Also, I do not know why the class need the functions when I see the digram you draw. I think most functions in router_info abc are related to post action after CRUDing. It can have more abstract naming then I felt. 

- Backend is a little bit confusing naming. I imagine what a pair of frontend would be when I heard the word backend. So imhm, 'driver' which is used generally in Neutron is more appropriate

- LinuxBackend is little bit like the same thing. If there is no WindowBackend,  I think driver naming would be more related to implementation detail (like OVN, OVS)"}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 05:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 05:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

rebase ^'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 05:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 07:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 07:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

PS3 contains more refactor changes. PS4 is focused on going back to RouterInfo (instead of LinuxRouterInfo) and calling the base class BaseRouterInfo.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-03-04 09:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/639605/4 : FAILURE in 2h 12m 14s'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-04 17:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Yang, thanks for your thoughts. I'm ok with "Driver" instead of "Backend". In terms of the functions in the classes I drew, don't take them too seriously as I only show a few and possibly those can be changed too. I hope you feel more comfortable after I renamed LinuxRouterInfo back to RouterInfo. I am trying to get this patch to a point where it's sort of mid-way to get to the diagram I attached (which is absolutely out of scope for Stein). And yes, the mixins are big trouble and I confess they are not as backend-independent as I would like them to be at this point, but it's a bit closer. Today I will try to get the new func test failures fixed and rebase on top of your patch.'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-06 19:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-03-06 19:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2019-04-18 23:04:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 15070, 'date': '2019-04-19 01:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

With our continues development of DVR  Openflow solution and the evolution of OVN, we have done some analysis. The feature set in OVN is richer than the current DVR solution & is gaining momentum in the community. So we are intending to transition our DVR efforts to OVN and stop further development in DVR. We believe this will better help community and networking project. Intel will be glad to help customers transition from DVR to OVN. Let us know if you have any feedback to us.'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2019-04-19 02:04:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> With our continues development of DVR  Openflow solution and the

 > help customers transition from DVR to OVN. Let us know if you have
 > any feedback to us.

I'm curios about the 'some analysis'. Would you mind to share the what you found?"}, {'account_id': 9396, 'date': '2020-01-28 18:13:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Clean up.'}]

'}, {'created': '2019-03-04 05:51:21.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

Mostly finished but still WIP.

L3 agent refactor: towards backend-agnostic agent

This patch fundamentally does 3 things to make the l3 agent.py agnostic
of which backend is being used to implement the routers being deployed.

1. Introduce the Backend class hierarchy
Backend is a abstract class meant to normalize the operations that any
backend (such as Linux or OVS) should implement. Its children will
carry out backend-specific operations. At the moment, Backend will
only be for operations that the agent as a whole requires. Operations
needed in the context of a specific Router that is being managed are
not to be fulfilled by the Backend hierarchy.

2. Refactor RouterInfo a little bit by moving some code to Backend
children instead (specifically to LinuxBackend since Linux is the only
backend currently available). The code that has been moved is thus
code that is required by the agent as a whole, not by any particular
router. Additinally, RouterInfo gets renamed to LinuxRouterInfo and
a new parent class is created called "RouterInfo". The latter
RouterInfo is an abstract class aims at unifying the interface to be
supported by any backend implementation of RouterInfo, very much like
the Backend class. The difference in the case of RouterInfo is that
it will be meant for operations in the context of particular routers.

3. Modify agent.py/mixins to make use of both RouterInfo and Backend.
Specifically, it is making use of LinuxRouterInfo and LinuxBackend
since those are the only backends available at this point. A lot of
renaming in many different files has been done too, mainly due to
original RouterInfo becoming LinuxRouterInfo.

The commit message will be shortened once there's documentation.

Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: If191289ca380b9c946ae1954f724e37240b0c839
'}, {'created': '2019-03-04 07:01:48.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

not to be fulfilled by the Backend hierarchy.

2. Refactor RouterInfo a little bit by moving some code to Backend
children instead (specifically to LinuxBackend since Linux is the only
backend currently available). The code that has been moved is thus
code that is required by the agent as a whole, not by any particular
router. Additionally, a new parent class is created called
"BaseRouterInfo". This base class aims to fit well with patch 620349.
BaseRouterInfo is an abstract class to unify the interface to be
supported by any backend implementation of RouterInfo, very much like
the Backend class. The difference in the case of RouterInfo is that
it will be meant for operations in the context of particular routers.

The commit message will be shortened once there's documentation.

Related-Bug: #1705536

commit_message:
L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

This patch fundamentally does 2 things to make the l3 agent.py agnostic
of which backend is being used to implement the routers being deployed.

1. Introduce the Backend class hierarchy
Backend is a abstract class meant to normalize the operations that any
backend (such as Linux or OVS) should implement. Its children will
carry out backend-specific operations. At the moment, Backend will
only be for operations that the agent as a whole requires. Operations
needed in the context of a specific Router that is being managed are
not to be fulfilled by the Backend hierarchy.

2. Refactor RouterInfo a little bit by moving some code to Backend
children instead (specifically to LinuxBackend since Linux is the only
backend currently available). The code that has been moved is thus
code that is required by the agent as a whole, not by any particular
router. Additionally, this patch now depends on patch 620349, which
introduces BaseRouterInfo and the router_factory.
BaseRouterInfo is an abstract class to unify the interface to be
supported by any backend implementation of RouterInfo, very much like
the Backend class. The difference in the case of RouterInfo is that
it will be meant for operations in the context of particular routers.

Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: If191289ca380b9c946ae1954f724e37240b0c839
Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr

commit_message:
Introduce agent_backend L3 option

This patch introduces the agent_backend option to be
used in the L3 agent configuration file. The single
value supported as of now is "linux", reflecting the
backend that the L3 agent has always supported.

Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr
Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: I5f382631ba3ae2ec537380502b9c5070a04c25d0

commit_message:
Add new option to enable unbuildable images

I7a92b762f6a783f92ebca61e5595e1422a92df4f added checking for unbuildable
images when someone wants just templates (like TripleO for example).

But what if someone wants all images despite their buildability status?
Or wants to build for some new distro/arch combo?

--enable-unbuildable just ignores internal UNBUILDABLE_IMAGES list and
tries all images.

Change-Id: I20312b9719c6f5e3dca0b4198607ddae183152f1

for signal 15.

commit_message:
Fix kill-script

This change squashes two changes that are being backported from the
tripleo-ansible repo.  They are to the same file, which was relocated to
tripleo-ansible between Train and Ussuri.

Change https://review.opendev.org/703123: In the kill-script there is a
string "Unknown action ${SIG} for ${$CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}" which results in
a "bad substitution" error, as there is no variable named with what the
contents of the CT_NAME environment variable contains.  Remove the
extraneous '$'.

Change https://review.opendev.org/703128: The reason bug #1860155 was
triggered was because the kill script did not have a stanza for handling
the signal that was passed in, which is signal 15.  Since signal 15 is
unhandled, keepalived processes will still stick around.  Add handling
for signal 15.

Change-Id: Ib47fc73b498b6366efa4ae5b16855bd45cb3ec91
Fixes-Bug: #1860155

commit_message:
Fix ansible-runner when verbosity is > 0

This change updates the run_ansible_playbook method to ensure that we're not
attempting to re-open the ansible runner stdout property when executing a
task with a verbosity setting of > 0. When the property is read the tmp file
has already been cleaned up resulting in stacktrace. There's no value in
re-opening the property as stdout is already been presented to the user so
the offending code has been deleted.

Change-Id: I4ab300e8a2a70adb1f79334aee44fde31d2cfa70
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create default network for more compute tests

Chipping away at the referenced bug, this commit uses the
create_default_network class-level variable introduced via [1] to
trigger setup_credentials to create a default network for another test
case in which the problem was observed.

[1] Ia34fe3b41261de02918713c2a948e6c56554bf6f
Partial-Bug: #1844568

Change-Id: Ic500aff5adda66328c292c936eaa097253360ea4

commit_message:
Allow archival for big files

Archive any file over 10KB when artcl_gzip is set to true.

Remember that not all jobs running are yet using this role. We will
sort this aspect after enabling this role.

Molecule testing job should validate the archival logic.

Change-Id: I044cd56473762d6d5c9318e1c76e43b454b4c7b6
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/704044/

commit_message:
Ensure boolean is cast to bool

This will ensure all potential ansible accepted boolean operators are
trapped and handled correctly.

Change-Id: Ifbc293860cc81c0c689b127b2da8930f557a6ad5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 22:05:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix test_stamp_pattern to remove dependency of user supplied volume name

This Patch removes CONF.compute.volume_device_name dependency and
used remote_client get_disk function and get the newly attached
volume name and use that for mkfs rather than the user supplied
voulme name which is based on assumtion.

Note: Other testcase test_minimum_basic is using disks.count
(CONF.compute.volume_device_name) rather than volume name so
that needs no modification

Change-Id: I862d1ba55f45b09385057a51b0b52a851c19287e
Closes-Bug: #1852807
'}, {'created': '2019-12-16 20:53:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix test_stamp_pattern to remove dependency of user supplied volume name

This Patch removes CONF.compute.volume_device_name dependency and
use modified list_disks method to get the newly attached
volume name and use that for mkfs rather than the user supplied
voulme name which is based on assumtion.

Also modfied test_attach_detach testcase and unit test
for remote_client accordingly.

(CONF.compute.volume_device_name) rather than volume name so

commit_message:
Fix test_stamp_pattern to remove dependency of user supplied volume name

This patch removes CONF.compute.volume_device_name dependency and
use modified list_disks method to get the newly attached
device name and use that for mkfs rather than the user supplied
device name which is based on assumtion.

Also modfied test_attach_detach testcase and unit test
for remote_client accordingly.

Change-Id: I862d1ba55f45b09385057a51b0b52a851c19287e
Closes-Bug: #1852807

[{'created': '2019-10-31 13:58:58.000000000', 'message': "Add a new filter to auth.py

A new filter to tempest/lib/auth.py is added which will omit url's path
from version. This will be helpfull when an api prefix needs to be preserved
in the url in order to contact the right endpoint.

Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af
Close-bug: 1799981
"}, {'created': '2019-12-05 16:28:36.000000000', 'message': "Add a new filter to auth.py

A new filter to tempest/lib/auth.py is added which will omit url's path
from the given string. This will be helpfull when an api prefix needs to be
preserved in the url in order to contact the right endpoint.

Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af
Close-bug: 1799981
"}, {'created': '2020-01-19 02:02:35.000000000', 'message': 'Accept custom registered endpoints

Tempest modifies the base url fetched from endpoints by truncating the
whole path which is incorrect in case of registered endpoint with an
extra path, like in a case of Rados GW.

Normally a swift url is organised as host:port/info and
host:port/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/
But RadosGW API is organised as host:port/swift/info and
host:port/swift/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/config-ref/#swift-settings

Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af
Close-bug: 1799981

commit_message:
Accept custom registered endpoints

The review drops usage of skip_path() filter in the related tests
and uses raw_request() instead.

Normally a swift url is organised as host:port/info and
host:port/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/
But RadosGW API is organised as host:port/swift/info and
host:port/swift/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/config-ref/#swift-settings

Close-bug: 1799981
Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af

I like the gist of it. However, I am still unclear on the globally unique domain name requirement. If we keep this requirement, in theory, the auth API should not need to change. i.e. user should not required to specify the full path.

I haven't put much thought into assignment implications yet. But I don't see any big land minds in the path."}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-07-05 16:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2016-07-05 17:33:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

I think we are essentially circling back to the same issue, which is how to uniquely identify a domain or project in the hierarchy while still maintaining V3 semantic. We simply can't have the cake and eat it too. Seem like we are destined for V4 on this one. :-)"}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-07-05 17:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Guang...I don't understand which API this proposal would break. We don't have nested domains today, so there are no existing auth examples that can break (unlike the proposal of doing this with project names). So we can have our cake, with a cherry on top for good measure"}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-07-05 17:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2016-07-05 17:57:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

What I meant was with this spec, like hierarchical projects, merely specifying the domain name itself will no longer be adequate. From now on, domain will always be referred to by its entire path. So the impact is more or less the same as hierarchical projects right?'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-07-05 20:50:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

the outcome of the keystone meeting on 7/5/2016 was that we should let ayoung and henry duke it out in person at the midcycle (on july 19th). both parties have valid points and this topic deserves further discussion. if necessary we can give this spec an FFE for newton'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-07-07 15:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-07 15:30:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

- gate-keystone-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/40/332940/8/check/gate-keystone-specs-python27/5698a45/ : SUCCESS in 4m 56s'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-07-08 18:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

waiting for the midcycle to see if this one lands in newton, early in ocata, or at all.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-07-11 04:46:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2

The -2 is being placed here as we have reached Spec Proposal Freeze for Newton. If you would like to have this considered for a SPF exception, please sent a message to the development mailing list with justification for the exception. Alternatively, you may target a new release.

I realize we already agreed to discuss this at the midcycle, this -2 is simply administrative so we don't accidentally merge this spec in the mean time."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-20 15:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

commit_message:
Support nested domains to provide additional project namespaces

Allow customers to utilise sub-domains to create namespaces
within a parent domain, so as to alleviate the restrictions of
project name constraints.

This spec is indended as an alternative to the proposals for
relaxing the project name constraints and supporting
hierarchical project naming, see:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/310048
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318605

Change-Id: I9e65d595b18ee3e498176d057f0f1ee1a68ad572
Implements: blueprint hierarchical-domains

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14030, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:27:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:36:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(14 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:37:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Ops, I provided a couple of comments, that still valid, in the patch set 6, when you sent that new one, can you take a look at this one?'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:49:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-2

(2 comments)

This cannot be a "general use" part of the API imo. I'm going to stick by my concerns. I really want, if this is going to be implemented, it being an ADMIN only action [meaning in the system-scope kind of world, it is a cloud-admin action].

I think we have a lot of issues with this proposal outlined here:

What occurs when an ID is in conflict? UUID4 is effectively unique, but with this system it is possible that someone can squat on an ID or could select an ID that could be UUID (e.g., "deadbeefdeadbeefdeadbeefdeadbeef") and prevent folks from another cloud from consuming it.

I also do not want people to specify (and require sanitization of the input) the IDs. Keystone has long stated it controls the IDs internally, this is to prevent failures based upon input of data (if someone sets a non-UUID form ID).

-2 is for in-line comment regarding fernet across multiple non-replicated keystones. I am very much not comfortable with this from a security standpoint.

I'll walk back my -2 to a -1 once that goal/support is removed from the spec.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2017-12-18 17:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

As an addendum, all IDs specified will need to 100% conform to UUID (and be validated as such). This must be included in the spec as well.'}, {'account_id': 14030, 'date': '2017-12-19 15:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 12342, 'date': '2017-12-19 17:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2017-12-19 18:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Walking back to a -1 (fernet bits that justified the -2 have been removed). I will do a more in-depth read with comments of the latest patch.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-12-19 19:45:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Walking back to a -1 (fernet bits that justified the -2 have been
 > removed). I will do a more in-depth read with comments of the
 > latest patch.

This was discussed at length in our weekly keystone meeting [0]. There was an alternative driver proposed that might help fix this issue too. I also sent a note to the operator list so that we can collect some more feedback on the performance issues of k2k [1].

[0] http://eavesdrop01.openstack.org/meetings/keystone/2017/keystone.2017-12-19-18.00.log.html#l-69
[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2017-December/014697.html'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Morgan Fainberg with the following votes:

* Code-Review-1 by Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
'}]

commit_message:
Repropose Expiring Group Membership for Ussuri

Add federated users to the groups that they receive from the mapping rules.
This membership is only carried by the token and not persisted in the
database. The membership expires, but can be renewed when the user
authenticates with the same group.

Previously approved for Train, fell into backlog, reproposing for Ussuri.

Change-Id: Ie133c14ffba5e4189265920759bfb5e1391f1189
Partial-Bug: 1809116

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-25 21:33:06.000000000', 'message': "WIP Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is very early and rough. Basically, it's an outgrowth of
os-client-config's vendor profile documents, but adapted based on
lessons learned - and then suggested as a mostly-static document
deployers can deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can add one -
adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is not super hard.
Whereas adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a document, it's also something that a user can just store locally
if they happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document.

That said - this patch in its current form is a complete brain-dump -
which is probably easy to see in the form of the prose. Help making the
text be less bad would be highly appreciated. Also - this is a proposal
for a thing which doens't exist and also doesn't have an associated REST
service to go with - which makes it a weird beast that has zero home in
our current governance structure. But the API-WG are the stewards of
helping make our APIs more consumable.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090
"}, {'created': '2017-04-27 12:45:06.000000000', 'message': "Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is an outgrowth of os-client-config's vendor profile documents,
but adapted based on lessons learned and suggested as a mostly-static
document deployers should deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can (and
should) add one - adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is
not super hard. Adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a mostly static document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a static document, it's also something that a user can just store
locally as we currently do with os-client-config vendor profiles if they
happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document. In fact, to start, os-client-config can
continue to store and ship documents for known public clouds until such
a time as those clouds start deploying them themselves.

If this is accepted, the ultimate intent would be to add support to
devstack (and the other upstream deployment projects) to add one to the
clouds they deploy, add tempest tests for it and propose it for
inclusion in DefCore guidelines. However, as this doesn't have an
associated REST service, it's a little bit of a weird beast that doesn't
have an explicit home in our current governance structure, so it would
probably be good, if the API-WG likes it, to make a proposal to the TC
to get buy in - and maybe a provisional nod from the Interop Working Group
that the idea of adding it to the guidelines at least wouldn't be
rejected outright.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090

commit_message:
Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is an outgrowth of os-client-config's vendor profile documents,
but adapted based on lessons learned and suggested as a mostly-static
document deployers should deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can (and
should) add one - adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is
not super hard. Adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a mostly static document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a static document, it's also something that a user can just store
locally as we currently do with os-client-config vendor profiles if they
happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document. In fact, to start, os-client-config can
continue to store and ship documents for known public clouds until such
a time as those clouds start deploying them themselves.

If this is accepted, the ultimate intent would be to add support to
devstack (and the other upstream deployment projects) to add one to the
clouds they deploy, add tempest tests for it and propose it for
inclusion in DefCore guidelines. However, as this doesn't have an
associated REST service, it's a little bit of a weird beast that doesn't
have an explicit home in our current governance structure, so it would
probably be good, if the API-WG likes it, to make a proposal to the TC
to get buy in - and maybe a provisional nod from the Interop Working
Group that the idea of adding it to the guidelines at least wouldn't be
rejected outright.

We know more things we can put in to this from os-client-config - but
let's start small-ish and see how we get.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090

neutron and related advanced networking services check existences of resources for DELETE operation, so we cannot switch the behavior soon...."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-12-13 16:07:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Explicit is better than implicit. It's easy to catch error 404, but it's hard to know if your operation actually did something in your proposal. If I make a typo in my deletion command, I'd prefer to know it.

Still -0 on this."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-12-13 16:10:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

And with my ironic hat on, I doubt we're going to follow this guideline."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-12-13 16:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

This reads correctly.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-12-13 16:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm upgrading my vote to proper -1 for these reasons:

1. I think this guideline will lead to more user confusion. It does not match how many common things behave. You issue 'rm /file' and it fails if /file is not a thing. You need to explicitly add -f to make it not fail.

2. DELETE (the English word) is an action, it assumes an object. At least for my non-native understanding it's not correct to delete something that never existed. So I don't agree with interpreting the DELETE word the way it is interpreted in this proposal.

3. As a responsible API-SIG member I don't feel comfortable landing something I'm not going to at least try obeying in the projects I work on. Ironic returns 404 in this case, and it has always been stated explicitly in its API design specifications."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:17:43.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Morgan Fainberg with the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
'}]

commit_message:
Add idempotent DELETE guidance

This patch adds guidance to the HTTP methods about how to interpret the
DELETE method. As discussed at the September 2018 PTG, we want to
encourage an idempotent interpretation of DELETE to reduce the amount of
error handling that clients need to implement.

Change-Id: I1ce452e4553a67f7249196dc0c2d4e3c83ef0d3f

commit_message:
Allow services to override proxy creation

Swift doesn't do version discovery, it's just simply not a thing.
Add a mechanism to allow the object-store service_description to
create the proxy object itself bypassing the discovery process.

Change-Id: I0227848701202575ed7da2e216a4a2eaacee3eda

commit_message:
Fix resource layer object interactions with weird chars

'/' is a valid swift object name, as is anything else. So we need to
url quote the names, and we need to join them not using our urljoin
function.

Add a hook point to do this and use it in the resource layer.

Change-Id: If5e757d28932e810f1da54b8b825a2b760d02698

commit_message:
CI: Fix symlinks to failed logs

Stop renaming files. Swift should be able to serve text/plain files
based on content, not extension.

Failed logs symlinks were broken because we stopped gzipping log
files and improperly rewrote the logic there.

Change-Id: Idddf51730821644948f51577807f5beaa18c6262
(cherry picked from commit 4a0182f15acbabc88df0aa660abce81d61f528da)
(cherry picked from commit 067770667cf62195580a8406dda1219d6a709f57)

commit_message:
Ensure we don't pass empty addresses to lsp_set_addresses

If we somehow have an empty set of addresses, lsp_set_addresses
will fail. This instead calls db_clear() on the addresses field if
we are trying to set it to empty.

Closes-bug: #1860560

Change-Id: Ied92eb85b74e63a7317d50970b5131fb49e3e4b0

commit_message:
Add package information to the dashboard-plugin relation

Add 'conflicting-packages' and 'install-packages' keys to the
relation so that a plugin can notify the openstack-dashboard charm that
it needs packages installed and what original packages will conflict
with them.

Change-Id: I962ec558b8dd1f765c6104d5ae61edd41c03affe
Related-Bug: #1853851

commit_message:
Use mariabackup for database backups

Kolla ansible switched its database backup support to mariabackup from
xtrabackup due to incompatibilities. See
https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla/+bug/1843043 for details.

Change-Id: Ib95771f09fd6d5e71a2af471de47f811e1cab88b
Related-Bug: #1843043
Story: 2006952
Task: 37634

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Use internal API endpoints in overcloud API interaction

Connections default to 'public' interface when attempting to run
openstack commands.  This breaks setups where the network hosts are
separate from the controllers.

This change adds an ``openstack_interface`` variable to select the
correct endpoint to use, which defaults to ``internal``.

Co-Authored-By: Michael Senizaiz <michael@r-hpc.com>

Change-Id: Ifa766d2cc3ed7077f03c571398072ad5117701c6
Story: 2006814
Task: 37374

[{'created': '2019-11-11 17:57:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix use of IPA images in Bifrost without a checksum

Ironic now provides DIB-built CentOS images at
https://tarballs.openstack.org/ironic-python-agent/dib/files. However,
if Bifrost is configured to use these, then the 'kayobe seed service
deploy' command fails because the checksum files are not available.

This change fixes the issue by allowing
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_kernel_checksum_url' and
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_ramdisk_checksum_url' to be overridden to empty
strings, indicating that there is no checksum.

Very similar to the issue fixed in https://review.opendev.org/688359 for
the overcloud.

Change-Id: If73cebb95c7d0596dc8087112fc19398a113f0cc
Story: 2006715
Task: 37407
"}]
commit_message:
Fix use of IPA images in Bifrost without a checksum

Ironic now provides DIB-built CentOS images at
https://tarballs.openstack.org/ironic-python-agent/dib/files. However,
if Bifrost is configured to use these, then the 'kayobe seed service
deploy' command fails because the checksum files are not available.

This change fixes the issue by allowing
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_kernel_checksum_url' and
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_ramdisk_checksum_url' to be overridden to empty
strings, indicating that there is no checksum.

Very similar to the issue fixed in https://review.opendev.org/688359 for
the overcloud.

Change-Id: If73cebb95c7d0596dc8087112fc19398a113f0cc
Story: 2006715
Task: 37407

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-08 11:29:18.000000000', 'message': "Fix kayobe overcloud provision without seed in limit

If you run 'kayobe overcloud provision' for the first time on a system,
and do not include the seed in the limit (e.g. --limit overcloud), then
the following error is seen:

    Destination directory /etc/kolla/bifrost/inventory/host_vars does
    not exist

This is because the first play in ansible/kolla-bifrost-hostvars.yml
executes against the seed. This is not ideal, as the --limit argment is
useful with this command, as a way to provision specific nodes.

This change fixes the issue by moving the initialisation tasks to the
second play which is targeted at the overcloud group. The run_once
parameter ensures it happens once.

Change-Id: I7dff72a50f0592a3564c9d84d684db562c30626a
Story: 2006757
Task: 37247
"}, {'created': '2019-11-11 09:47:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix kayobe overcloud provision without seed in limit

This is because the first play in ansible/kolla-bifrost-hostvars.yml
